title: Patch Stitching Data Augmentation for Cancer Classification in Pathology Images
author: Jiamu Wang (School of Electrical Engineering, Korea University), Chang-Su Kim (School of Electrical Engineering, Korea University), Jin Tae Kwak (School of Electrical Engineering, Korea University), ...
relevance_why: The proposed data augmentation technique for pathology images can inspire novel methods for audio-data scarcity issues, particularly in tasks like audio generation where labeled data is limited.
background: The task involves enhancing classification accuracy for colorectal cancer pathology images using synthesized data from existing labeled images to combat data scarcity and imbalance.
contribution: This paper introduces the Patch Stitching image Synthesis (PaSS) method to solve the problem of data scarcity in computational pathology, achieving improved classification accuracy in colorectal cancer detection.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional data augmentation methods are limited to simpler transformations (e.g., flipping, rotation), which may not sufficiently enrich datasets.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by creating synthetic images from different segments of existing images, thereby providing more diverse training data than conventional methods.

key_innovation: Generates new synthetic images by stitching together identical regions from multiple pathology images within the same category.
real_world_impact: Improves diagnostic accuracy in colorectal cancer pathology, which can facilitate faster and more reliable cancer detection in clinical settings.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention limitations but the synthetic data may not fully capture the variability in unseen data from different sources.

new_terms.Patch Stitching image Synthesis (PaSS): **Patch Stitching image Synthesis (PaSS)** is a data augmentation technique designed to enhance the training dataset by creating synthetic images from existing ones through segment stitching.
